trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised placebo controlled crossover trial to evaluate the effects of different doses of taurocholic acid in a suppository on gastrointestinal hormone secretion and appetite in healthy humans.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised placebo controlled crossover trial to evaluate the effects of different doses of taurocholic acid in a suppository on gastrointestinal hormone secretion and appetite in healthy humans.

interventions.interventions: Each healthy volunteers will undergo four studies (3 with different doses of taurocholic acid 500mg, 1000mg, and 1500mg and one with control), in double-blind, randomised fashion, separated by 3 - 7 days. On each day the test material will be administered as a suppository.
interventions.comparator: Suppository containing vehicle only containing no additional component

primaryOutcome.outcome: Plasma concentrations of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), Peptide YY (PYY), and oxyntomodulin
primaryOutcome.timepoint: T= -5, 10, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180 min, where the suppository is administered at T=0 min

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appetite scores by visual analogue questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: T= -5, 10, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180 min, where the suppository is administered at T=0 min

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Food intake from an ad libitum buffet meal
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Offered over 30 minutes, from 180 - 210 min after the suppository is administered

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Medications affecting gut function Alcohol intake >20g daily or cigarette smoking Significant gastrointestinal disease or surgery Impaired liver or renal function Blood donation within 3 months

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study aims to establish whether taurocholic acid, administered as a suppository, can stimulate secretion of the gut peptides GLP-1, PYY, and oxyntomodulin, and suppress subsequent appetite and food intake. This information could be useful in designing treatments for type 2 diabetes and obesity.
